1.text: See, my eye has seen all this, my ear has heard and understood it.

2.text: What you know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior to you.

3.text: Surely I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.

4.text: But you are forgers of lies, you are all physicians of no value.

5.text: O that you would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom.

6.text: Hear now my reasoning, and listen to the pleadings of my lips.

7.text: Will you speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?

8.text: Will you accept his person? will you contend for God?

9.text: Is it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocks another, do you so mock him?

10.text: He will surely reprove you, if you do secretly accept persons.

11.text: Shall not his excellency make you afraid? and his dread fall on you?

12.text: Your remembrances are like to ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay.

13.text: Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.

14.text: Why do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in my hand?

15.text: Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain my own ways before him.

16.text: He also shall be my salvation: for an hypocrite shall not come before him.

17.text: Hear diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.

18.text: Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.

19.text: Who is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shall give up the ghost.

20.text: Only do not two things to me: then will I not hide myself from you.

21.text: Withdraw your hand far from me: and let not your dread make me afraid.

22.text: Then call you, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer you me.

23.text: How many are my iniquities and sins? make me to know my transgression and my sin.

24.text: Why hide you your face, and hold me for your enemy?

25.text: Will you break a leaf driven to and fro? and will you pursue the dry stubble?

26.text: For you write bitter things against me, and make me to possess the iniquities of my youth.

27.text: You put my feet also in the stocks, and look narrowly to all my paths; you set a print on the heels of my feet.

28.text: And he, as a rotten thing, consumes, as a garment that is moth eaten.
